chapter.htmlHeader: How should I confirm a diagnosis of hypercalcaemia?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
If a diagnosis of hypercalcaemia is suspected:

  • Arrange a serum calcium blood test and interpret the result.
    • Avoid prolonged application of a tourniquet during venepuncture.
    • Ensure the laboratory result shows the calcium concentration is adjusted ('corrected') for the serum albumin concentration. Note: the calculation of a corrected calcium value is usually completed by the laboratory, but may be inaccurate at extreme albumin concentrations, or if there is paraproteinaemia or acidosis.
    • Do not measure ionised calcium when testing for primary hyperparathyroidism.
  • Classify the severity of hypercalcaemia, and manage appropriately.
    • Mild — adjusted calcium concentration is 2.6–3.00 mmol/L.
    • Moderate — adjusted calcium concentration is 3.01–3.40 mmol/L.
    • Severe — adjusted calcium concentration is greater than 3.40 mmol/L.
  • If the person has severe hypercalcaemia or has severe symptoms, arrange emergency hospital admission for further assessment and management. See the section on Management for more information.
    • Do not routinely investigate people with unexplained severe hypercalcaemia or severe symptoms.
  • If the person is asymptomatic or has symptoms with mild or moderate hypercalcaemia, repeat the serum calcium level after one week to confirm the diagnosis.
  • If a diagnosis of hypercalcaemia is confirmed on repeat testing, classify the severity of hypercalcaemia:
    • Mild — adjusted calcium concentration is 2.6–3.00 mmol/L.
    • Moderate — adjusted calcium concentration is 3.01–3.40 mmol/L.
    • Severe — adjusted calcium concentration is greater than 3.40 mmol/L.
  • If the person has severe hypercalcaemia on repeat testing or has severe symptoms, arrange emergency hospital admission for further assessment and management. See the section on Management for more information.
    • Do not routinely investigate people with unexplained severe hypercalcaemia or severe symptoms.
  • If the person has mild or moderate hypercalcaemia on repeat testing, arrange further investigations in primary care to determine the underlying cause, depending on clinical judgement.
    • If the person has a known malignancy which is suspected to be the underlying cause, see the Scenario on Hypercalcaemia - known malignancy for more information on ongoing management.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on the confirmation of suspected hypercalcaemia are based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) clinical guideline Hyperparathyroidism (primary): diagnosis, assessment and initial management [NICE, 2019], and expert opinion in review articles on primary care testing [Smellie et al, 2008], on hypercalcaemia [Meng, 2015; Minisola, 2015; Turner, 2017], on parathyroid disorders [Pallan et al, 2012; Michels, 2013; Insogna, 2018], and on hypercalcaemia of malignancy [Zagzag, 2018].

  • The recommendation to avoid prolonged tourniquet application is based on the fact this may be associated with increased protein-bound calcium and total calcium levels [Smellie et al, 2008; Meng, 2015].
  • The recommendation to ensure the serum calcium concentration is adjusted ('corrected') for the serum albumin concentration is based on the fact that about 45% of calcium in blood is bound to plasma proteins, particularly albumin. If serum protein concentrations fluctuate, total serum calcium levels may also vary [Smellie et al, 2008; Meng, 2015; Minisola, 2015].
  • The information that serum calcium concentration may be inaccurate at extreme albumin concentrations is based on expert opinion in review articles [Pallan et al, 2012; Meng, 2015; Minisola, 2015].
    • Increased protein binding can occur in people with hypoalbuminaemia due to dehydration or paraproteinaemia, for example. Conversely, hypoalbuminaemia due to malnutrition or chronic illness may result in a falsely normal or low serum calcium [Pallan et al, 2012; Zagzag, 2018].
  • The information that serum calcium concentration may be inaccurate if there is acidosis is based on the fact changes in blood pH can also affect serum calcium levels (acidosis reducing binding of albumin-ionised calcium complexes, and alkalosis enhancing it) [Meng, 2015; Minisola, 2015].
  • The recommendation to repeat the serum calcium level is largely based on the NICE clinical guideline, which does not specify the time interval between repeat measurements [NICE, 2019].
    • The recommendation to repeat the blood test after one week is based on expert opinion in a review article, which advises a diagnosis of hypercalcaemia should be made if there is a raised serum calcium in two samples at least one week apart over a period of three months [Minisola, 2015]. This is supported by expert opinion in additional review articles that the diagnosis is made on the basis of two blood results [Michels, 2013; Meng, 2015; Insogna, 2018]. This approach is supported by the expert opinion of previous external reviewers of this CKS topic.
  • The recommendation to arrange emergency admission if there is severe hypercalcaemia is based on the fact this can be life-threatening and may need intravenous hydration and bisphosphonate treatment, as well as treatment of underlying disease where appropriate [Minisola, 2015].
